f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (02:13): does anyone else find it ironic that with the moratorium on discussing spec splitting still in effect, we're instead having a meta discussion about the moratorium itself?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (02:13): I wonder how that's any better
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:13): what's the moratorium about again?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:13): i mean, what can't we talk about?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (02:14): it's about why we should or should not split the spec into language vs. implementation specs
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:14): oh
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:14): i wish i knew why anyone would want to do that and what it would actually mean
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:15): and why they've never asked for it for any other spec...
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:15): anyway
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:15): such a split would be silly
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (02:15): because those who've asked for it are used to specs like HTML4, XHTML1 and XHTML2, which only specificy the conforming language
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:15): that's not accurate
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (02:16): well, it's a rough approximation
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:16): HTML4 and XHTML2 define the language and the error handling and the processing requirements
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (02:16): error handling?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (02:16): maybe a little
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:16): (it's just that they do so in a woefully inadequate manner)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:17): (for both the language and the processing requirements)
8b7a61a6e9bd5b8977b7b3f02a425adc (02:34): wouldn't XHTML2's error handling be mostly defined by the XML-ness of it?
8b7a61a6e9bd5b8977b7b3f02a425adc (02:34): or lack of error handling as the case may be
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:36): there's lots of possible errors other than syntax-level errors

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (03:00): though I'm not sure what they're meant to be linking to.  I added the # manually and it took me back to the same spot. So they don't appear to go anywhere
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:02): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: they're just intended as a convenience for people who want to link to/bookmark the descriptions
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (03:03): I clicked on them expecting them to take me to a description of the syntax for the coords attribute value, but was out of luck
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (03:03): from what I can tell, thats simply not defined

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (03:04): wow, is Roy surprised by the fact that the name attribute on <a> is no longer considered conforming, or the fact that browsers still have to process it despite that?
f47636673b14c54021a69dc06f6a19fb (03:05): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: mischaracterization of what Roy is showing
f47636673b14c54021a69dc06f6a19fb (03:06): Think out of your box

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:07): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: the "d:rectangle", etc., stuff should be links to datatype/microsyntax definitions. that part is a bug that I'll need to fix later
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (03:07): you're being rather cryptic today
f47636673b14c54021a69dc06f6a19fb (03:07): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: I guess the log of this channel unfortunately or fortunately gives borders to my expression

f47636673b14c54021a69dc06f6a19fb (03:09): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: Roy is making a point on declarative markup, and shows that the spec is mainly defined through the eye of browsers, which I think too. You might not agree with that because you are in your own browser box (not a reproach).

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (03:10): If Roy picked an attribute that was actually conforming, like for instance, the target attribute, he may have a point.  Its definition isn't the easiest to understand from a web developer's perspective.
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (03:10): "The target  attribute, if present, must be a valid browsing context name or keyword. User agents use this name when following hyperlinks."
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:10): this is all stuff that will be seen when i write the filtered view
f47636673b14c54021a69dc06f6a19fb (03:11): This is not markup :) exactly what Roy said
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (03:14): yeah. It wouldn't hurt to have non-normative, explanatory descriptions of what attributes mean or what function they perform
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (03:15): (although that will be in the authoring guide)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:15): any cases where that's missing are unintentional omissisons
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:15): in particular, the APIs are especially bad about this
f47636673b14c54021a69dc06f6a19fb (03:16): I wonder why the fear of normative for a declarative markup. This mesmerizes me.
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (03:16): yeah. For some attributes, it's not too bad actually. Like the seamless attribute description is quite good, as are the width and height attributes.
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (03:17): well, perhaps it could be normative. Those 3 attrs have normative descriptions
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:36): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: I fixed the links -- thanks for the heads-up
